Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about electromagnetism and how it ties in with the basics of physics we learned last semester.
Electricity and Magnetism, how to do tough integrations, and how to problem solve. This class really stretched my thinking to the limit, especially on the homework.
I learned about electro-magnetics and ways to approach solving complicated word problems.
This course was a comprehensive introduction for me to electricity and magnetism that built on material covered in 180.
After taking this course, I have developed a strong understand of  electricity and magnetism within circuits.
I learned how to deal with electromagnetism
more work on drawings and projections this semester. the work was more conceptual with less difficult or complicated math problems.
You learn a lot about circuits, electric fields, electricity, and magnetic fields. a lot of info.

Learning physics, as taxing of a process as it is, is a useful thing. I definitely understand better now how the world works and this class has in many ways informed how I interpret the other science I have learned (having no real understanding of physics). I really enjoyed doing the psets. They're difficult but doing them in groups really makes it manageable and fun, and the study halls and office hours ensure that anybody who wants to can do it in a group. The exams are tough, but overall I definitely learned a ton and was challenged in a good way.

As with all of professor Steinacker's courses, PHYS181 helped me to develop a very deep understanding of the concepts of electric fields, magnetic fields, their interaction, and the forces that they produce.

Although there are only 2 topics for the entire course (electricity and magnetism), there is a lot to learn! Circuits (RL, LC, RLC), Biot-Savart Law, Ampere's Law, Lorentz law/force, solenoids, electric fields, capacitors, generators, Gauses' Law, lots of kinds of flux, etc.

I learned physics concepts related to electricity and magnetism and how to apply them to problems. I practiced working through difficult problems step by step and also worked on when to use certain formulas and how to adapt them for different contexts.
E&M Physics!
some E and M stuff
I learned the principles of electricity and magnetism. I also learned how to approach certain problems like those dealing with circuits.
I greatly improved my skills both in physics and in critical thinking.
We learned the basics of electronics and magnetism for an introductory physics class. It didn't use much hard calculus and it was full of understanding circuits, and magnets and their relationship.
In this course, I learned how to take a broad approach to solving difficult problems, and how to apply knowledge in new ways.

We covered topics in electrostatics, magnetism, circuits, and induction. You definitely don't need Math 120 to manage the math basis in Physics 181 -- Professor Steinacker is also happy to work with you if you feel overwhelmed by the math you do need.

This course improved my ability to do calculus, problem solve, and understand physics-related concepts. It required a development of time-management, prioritization, and speed in order to complete assignments, as well as an uptick in studying to pass exams.
Mainly problem solving skills.
Electricity and magnetism knowledge, definitely.

This course provides a solid overview of the topics of electricity and magnetism, from the properties of static and moving charges, electric and magnetic fields, circuits, electric and magnetic flux, induction, electric and magnetic forces, and the synthesis of these concepts. In learning these concepts, the problem sets reinforce a commitment to challenging problems that require many different types of thinking, and the application of problem-solving strategies.
None. Terrible teacher with awful lectures.

As in Physics 180, I continued to develop my ability to do physics -- i.e. clearly reason through the flow of energy in various physical situations. This semester, we focused on electromagnetism, so I learned multiple ways of working with electrical and magnetic fields. My class also learned the fundamental properties of electricity (i.e. voltage, current direction in relation to an electric field, charge carriers, etc.). Also similar to Physics 180 was that higher-level mathematics involving differential equations, large systems of linear equations, and higher-level calculus periodically came up, though it was never crucial that students actually perform those higher-level mathematical operations.
I learned about electromagnetism
I learned about heavy mathematical applications of electricity and magnetism concepts.
This was an excellent physics course. I learned the foundations of classical physics, I learned to think critically and problem-solve, and developed excellent skills from this class.
I learned problem solving skills and university level physics.
Electricity and magnetism
learned about electricity and magnetism
I gained and understanding and appreciation for electronics and how they work.

I learned calculus based E&M physics. Outside of the obvious, this class really helps you understand derivations for physical quantities. I learned how to easily derive formulas I had previously taken for granted with integration. This intuition about how to approach a physics problem is definitely the main skill I learned from this class.
How to analyze the properties of electricity and magnetism using upper level math.
great problem solving skills
I gained an in-depth knowledge of physics.

This course taught me the basic concepts of electricity and magnetism. Before this course, I had never had any exposure to this material, but by the end I felt that I had a solid conceptual basis. This class also increased my confidence in addressing problems in a systematic and quantitative way.
Learned extensively about E&M and circuits.
A deeper understanding of electricity and magnetism, and how to approach problems you dont know how to solve.

I learned about electric and magnetic fields, circuits, and the work-energy theorem. I gained insight into the forces that electric and magnetic fields exert on charged particles and objects, as well as the induction of electromotive force by changing electric fields and the induction of magnetic fields by current flow.
We learned about various electromagnetism topics through a conceptual and problem-based approach. This course helped improve my ability to think about problems and find the best method to solve it.
I learned a lot about the general concepts of electromagnetism and magnetism. My knowledge of physics was greatly enhanced in this class, along with my knowledge of calculus.
I bettered my skills with integration and calculus in general.
I learned about the basics of electricity and magnetism as well as the beautiful value of working with peers.
I learned more about physics.
Learned standard electronics and magnetism- circuits, induction, etc.
I learned introductory physics.

I learned so much in taking this course. It was an excellent introduction to electricity and magnetism, and Professor Steinacker did a wonderful job of teaching us the relevant concepts. I learned how to think critically about physics problems and how to employ seemingly unrelated concepts together to solve multi-step questions. Although this course was difficult and definitely challenged my mathematical abilities, I feel like the skills and insights I developed far outweighed the extensive work and effort I had to constantly put into this class.
I learned many of the basics of electricity and magnetism and how they related to previous concepts learned in mechanics, such as torque and forces.
You learn a very in depth understanding of electricity and magnetism. I've heard this is more in depth than AP Physics C, but those who took this had no trouble for the most part.
Understanding of the concepts of physics and how it is applicable in the real world.
physics

I LEARNED ALL THE PHYSICS. No really, I took physics in high school and genuinely learned 0 things. But now I feel like I actually understand how mechanics and electricity are working, even if I can't always figure out a very complex mathematical question. I also developed the ability to balance some formidable psets, which is a very important skill, and learned how to work very hard for long hours at something I just wasn't naturally inclined toward but could learn all the same.
It was very intellectually stimulating and was a lot of work. The professor was great, but I still felt like we needed more review/preparation for the exams to really get an idea of what to study.

Strengths: Fantastic teacher, interesting course material.

Weaknesses: Homework is considerably harder than any of the exam material, which doesn't totally make sense to me.

Strengths:  Knowledgeable lecturer, wide availability for assistance, study halls, peer tutors, etc.  Manageable pace for lectures, and detailed problems worked out in class.  Partial credit for midterm corrections a HUGE plus, and homework is due only 1x/week, and is graded generously.

Weaknesses:  Emphasis on theoretical problems in both the homework and lecture, and applications could be taught much more effectively through one of the intro electrical engineering classes.  Understanding of inductance could be more condensed.

Strengths: Lots of office hours and peer tutor hours
Weaknesses: The pace of the course is fast, which makes it difficult to completely follow all of the complex topics being presented.

The course is well-structured and well-paced, and there are plenty of resources for getting help when you're stuck. Prof. Steinacker is the best professor I've ever had and really was the best thing about this course. I am not a physics student by any means, so this was the best I could have hoped for (though even Prof. Steinacker couldn't make me love physics).

the strengths is the instructor who is willing to help during office hours and answer questions after class. The weakness lies in the way the class is structured with the psets being so difficult they require cooperation in order to finish. The lectures too were dry and long making it hard to stay focused for the whole class
Shorter psets would be nice, they were unnecessarily long.
The PSETs are too difficult for the material we are learning. It is hard to conceptualize the major ideas of the course when we aren't learned the basics.

This course could be improved by having a range of types of problems on the pset, so have easier questions in the beginning and work up to the hard questions so students can learn how to do the problems in small amounts instead of having all hard problems on the pset. Also, in class should be much more examples of problems and less time spent teaching the concepts so intensely.

The strengths are definitely the psets and the online notes. I went to class every day, but I generally struggle to pay attention in class and it was really nice to have narrative notes to go through that helped me process what I didn't understand in class. The weaknesses are that this course is a TON of work, and that the test questions are sometimes tricky. I felt that no matter how much I studied and how thoroughly I understood every pset/review problem we'd been given, I still sometimes just could not understand the problems and for this reason at times it felt like it was testing innate capacity instead of learning ability. Still, it got better towards the end and the tests became less tricky and more complex applications of things we'd learned.

The strength is Steinacker, she cares so much and really wants people to fall in love with physics. The problem though is that the classes are absolutely massive so it is hard for people to actually get engaged. Also her notes aren't the best organized in the world, but neither are mine... The biggest weakness is that people will just go to study halls and get the answers to the homework without actually understanding how to actually solve the problems.
The class is excellent. Although very challenging, there are many resources available for students to aid the learning process.

I learned so much in this class, but the psets were so long that I at times was less engaged with the material as they took too long to do. I feel I could have gained the same amount of knowledge with less homework.

Strengths: the instructor, the grades. Once again, professor Steinacker has outdone herself. She continues to be one of the best professors I have ever had. She is so clear and detailed in her lectures and notes it's almost impossible not to learn anything. She also has gone out of her way to provide examples, notes, review sessions, etc. The grading is the same as 180 (aka VERY FAIR; 35% HW, 10% class participation, 15% each 2 midterms, 25% final) with the same exam corrections and curve!! 

Weaknesses: workload. Be prepared to die. The psets are even longer and more challenging than 180 (I know, trust me they get longer and harder even if it feels like that's not possible) and the amount of time you need to devote this class to not fail is significant.

The content of this course can be interesting, but the workload is extremely high. Professor Steinacker is incredible, and the number of office hours and study halls every week is extremely helpful for completing the work. That being said, the concepts can be complex and require reflection, and the work takes up a lot of time.

Strengths: Great professor who really cares about her students! The lectures are always clear, and office hours are a huge help.
Weaknesses: After the first exam, she started making all the homework problems required, which I thought was somewhat unnecessary.
the professor is quite bad at lecturing, though she is a nice person. Honestly, not sure if anything could make this course better.

This course is an incredible (and incredibly stressful!) introduction to physics. The material is harder than in 181, and less relevant for students who aren't interested in engineering. Professor Steinacker does her best to make the class relevant for everyone, but its definitely a physics course that focuses on classical physics which isn't that interesting and is math heavy. Class is well taught and though the homework assignments are very time consuming, they do help you learn. I would say a weakness of the class is that the homework are a little unreasonable. This last semester, our homework would be 10 questions long but only 5 would be graded (and we weren't told which 5). This was a little ridiculous to me, and not only stressed students out immensely, but really lowered out quality of work.
The course is structured so that you can get a lot of help outside of lecture to do the psets. However, I think lecture could be improved to be more helpful.

The course is very well facilitated to encourage student growth and learning. However, students are at a disadvantage if they do not have friends in the class. The professor is one of the best professors at Yale.

The class is very good because it pushes you to do really difficult problems but the grades were fair with test corrections and help at office hours. The class doesn't really have too many weaknesses, it is really well structured by Steinacker and you learn so much.

Strength: great structure, good introduction to physics. 

Weakness: a lot of topics to cover, leaving little time to go over each.

I feel the structure of this class could be much more effective. A flipped classroom, where we are provided with lecture notes and then spend class time discussing and asking questions, would probably be better, as I got little out of lecture and was often completely lost. This could also be remedied by making this class a three-times-a-week course where the classes are only 50 minutes, so we can learn in more manageable packets. The time required to be spent at office hours is also kind of absurd - 8-10 hours a week outside of class time. This was an incredibly taxing course, and could be more more manageable and interesting (as the material is sometimes exciting) if it were presented in a way that allow student to be ahead of the material, rather than always falling behind. It also seems geared toward students with strong physics/math backgrounds, which creates a group of people who are achieving great success and alienates those without the experience, leaving them to do endless work for a mediocre grade because the course, its exams, and its teaching structure isn't designed for them.

The strength of this course is the pace of the material and the clarity with which it is taught.

The major weakness of this course is the amount of work. The length and difficulty of problem sets can be overwhelming, and detracts from time needed to study for other courses.

I also was very frustrated at the amount of time it took for homework to be graded (>1 month in one case), and I often thought the grading was erratic and non-standard. Sometimes I would get 1 point off for getting a wrong answer, sometimes I would get 4 points off for having the wrong units. The feedback provided by the TAs through comments on canvas were also not very descriptive or helpful.

The professor is great. Her lectures are clear and organized. The notes on Canvas are also a great resource. She also really tries to make sure no one falls to for behind. 

The only two suggestions I have ate to have more sample problems/practice tests available AND to make the TAs do more. They were not that helpful and their grading was often unclear.

Great instructor who is willing to dedicate 10+ hours every week just in office hours, and great group of peer tutors. I think the homeworks tend to be ones that you cannot do unless you go to office hours. There is a need to check every answer on the homework at an office hour or peer tutoring session in order to get full credit for homework assignments - which also helps learn how to solve them in the process. However, some problems go beyond the concepts discussed in class, and are difficult to solve without going to office hours.

Some strengths are that the course is organized logically, and the pacing of topics is reasonable. The problem sets are created very thoughtfully with a lot of attention to detail, so that committing to the work involved in each homework assignment really does pay off in understanding the material you are responsible for. Professor Steinacker does her best to supplement the sometimes-tedium of lecture with interesting demonstrations, videos, or connections to the outside world, and make the material more relevant/accessible to people less familiar with electricity and magnetism. It could be improved by more frequent examples in lecture, because while a lot of class time is spent on derivations, the applications of those concepts are not clear in lecture, so they are less easily absorbed at the time of lecture. Additionally, the first midterm exam covered proportionally so much less material than the second midterm that it seemed like a non-intuitive way of measuring students' abilities consistently. Another point that might be improved is availability of TFs, as they often were not present or eager to help in study hall. The grading of homework assignments often took a bit too long to be helpful, and sometimes the feedback was sparse so I was left guessing what caused me to lose points.

Strengths: Online notes.
Weaknesses: She can not teach at all.  Makes PSETs way too hard for no reason and doesn't cover hardly any of the material necessary to do them. They are a complete waste of time and do not facilitate learning. Her lectures are not intuitive and she doesn't know how to explain things to the students.

I believe that my suggestions from Physics 180 still stand, so I will paste them in here.

This course can teach students (those who have the time to REALLY dig into it) quite a
LOT. And as time consuming as the problem-sets are, I believe that they teach valuable
approaches to general problem solving. I would assert that the problem sets are also good for
developing skills around teamwork, as it doesn't seem to be often that they're solved, totally
correctly, by a single individual who's working alone. However, it also seems to me that
students can neglect to learn how to actually study physics (building understandings of
concepts, learning how to derive & apply formulas, etc.) & simply focus on turning in P-sets.
Copying them IS totally possible, and, sadly, does happen. Of course, copying P-sets is also
reflected in exam performance. My only definite complaint would be that more accurate
practice tests and finals should be available, as the practice final that was provided was far
more difficult than the actual final. Also, I know that this would be difficult to provide for a
lecture of this size, but a larger emphasis on solving physics problems in general (i.e. more
feedback on the format & reasoning students provide to back up their answers) would be nice.
Teaching HOW to do physics, and not just providing knowledge of kinematics, dynamics, etc.,
is, I believe, important.
The professor is one of the strengths of this course, and also the amount of help that is available.

The psets are difficult, Dr. Steinecker is a smart woman, but I wish she would take into consideration the amount of time it takes to complete the psets. Not everyone can make time to go to her office hours, and without going to office hours, finishing the psets seems impossible.
This was a great course, but some of the lectures and homework assignments were too dense and hard to keep up with.

This was an excellent course! It was extremely well taught and the material was interesting. It was definitely a challenging course and the large lecture sizes made it slightly more difficult to stay focused and on top of the material. However, weekly psets and daily office hours really helped me station top of the material, learn it well, and succeed in the class.
I cannot think of any weakness of this course off the top of my head.  What you put in is what you get out, which is exactly how a class should be.

Strengths: Great professor who really cares about the course!
Weaknesses: The homework load became a little excessive, especially after the first exam.
I think the homework should be shorter or all the problems should be graded because a lot of the times they were repeated and similar.
The psets and time expectation were honestly grueling and unnecessary.

Overall, a super strong course. The only area for improvement I can think of is making the lectures a little simpler. That is, focus on some of the easier stuff and then get into the more complex material. I thought almost everything else was great. As a final (minor recommendation), a couple of the PSets were too long, but most of them were a solid, feasible length.

The weekly problem sets can be a grind, and I felt as though if students went to office hours they were given the answers. I was not able to go to office hours or study hall because of my schedule and always felt behind from these students.

I think Professor Steinacker does pretty much everything perfectly. The material is just difficult for many people who are required to take it, and who may also be bogged down by other challenging required courses. I just wish all pset problems were graded like last year, since they dont become as good learning tools and rather mainly means of getting graded weekly when only five are looked at by graders.
amazing amazing class! Professor Steinacker makes this class the best version possible
PSETS are too hard.
Honestley this was a beautiful class with an amazing professor and I wish I were more eloquent to express how great she was. The TAs were just bad at both grading and explaining.

The strengths of this course all stem from Professor Steinacker. The material isn't necessarily anything thrilling, unless you really love physics. Still, she managed to make it interesting and engaging. Her notes were detailed, her psets difficult but helpful, and her exams were fair. The office hours were also extremely helpful and allowed me to make the most of the course.

This course is a challenging course, with a very high workload. But, the course is worth it because as long as you put the time in, it is very rewarding. The Psets can take 10 hours a week, so maybe shorter psets would be nice.

The strengths of this course are the clear organization of the course material, the professor (Prof. Steinacker is amazing), and the consistent office hours and study hall. A weakness of this course is that some topics are not covered in very much depth, but this is an introductory physics course so the level of detail is to be expected.

Strengths: excellent professor, challenging but useful problem sets, fair exams, abundant resources for help
Improvements: problems sets were quite long and as a result many students end up rushing through without the time to fully understand and work out each problem carefully

The strength of the course is that the curriculum is well-organized. The main weakness is the homework. The homework is excessively long, and much more difficult than any examples presented in the lectures, to the point that it is at times impossible to do the work on our own without copying solutions from a study hall. If the homework was shorter/easier (or at least all solvable from concepts from the lectures), students would be able to do it on their own and not resort to copying every week.

This course is a very difficult course, and it is very time consuming. While I think it is great that students are rewarded for putting a lot of time into the PSETs by awarding them a high percentage of the final grade, I think the PSETs themselves are too long. I believe students would be more inclined to truly understand the problems themselves if they were given 6 or 7 problems a week as opposed to 9 or 10. As well, the tests were a bit difficult compared to the learned concepts.

The strengths of this course is that it has amazing resources for students who need it. Professor Adriane is probably the professor who invests the most time in her students, with (almost) unlimited office hours. The class also has study hall most days of the week which are SUPER helpful for doing the psets. Students get the chance to correct their midterms for the possibility of gaining up to 50% of their lost marks. Do not get me wrong, the content of this class is VERY challenging and you definitely need to put time to do the psets and study really well for the midterms. But Professor Adriane makes sure to provide every resource that we might need to succeed.

This course requires vast improvement. I can safely say that, because of this course specifically, I will no longer be taking Physics classes at Yale. While Adriane was a somewhat entertaining lecturer, she provided very little practical assistance in solving the difficult problems she gave on PSETs. Classes were devoted to deriving equations, but hardly any time was given to actually applying those equations to physical situations (which is obviously the entire point of physics). The PSETs subsequently were incredibly difficult and stressful, because Adriane had given us zero skills with which to solve these problems. The PSETs were hardly ever all graded before we were tested on the concepts in those PSETs, which meant there was no way to know what we didn't know prior to a test.

All around, this class was a massive disappointment. I highly recommend that the Physics department takes a close and careful look at this class, or risk losing countless more students like me who are actively being turned off of Physics at Yale.

This course is very intense and requires a lot from students, but the professor and TAs put just the same amount of effort in. Sometimes, the lectures are a little disorganized, but the general theme is always clear and applicable to the PSets.
This course did a good job at making you learn more about physics.
Very fair grading, interesting material, and instructive problem sets. TAs and peer tutors could have been more organized/prepared.
Course is taught by an excellent professor. Material is covered comprehensively.

The main strength of this course was its excellent organization. Professor Steinacker organized all of the information in a way that made sense and allowed concepts to clearly build off of one another throughout the semester. The main weakness was the length of Professor Steinacker's problem sets -- although they were very helpful, sometimes the length of the problem set was detrimental to my understanding of the material because I had to rush through the questions in order to finish on time.

The course covers so much information, which is inevitable but makes it hard to keep up. Additionally, the first test covered only a few topics despite us having covered a lot in class, which made the second test overwhelming with the amount we needed to know. However, all of the help sessions were very useful (office hours, reviews, study hall, etc.).

Strength: Very fair grading, and very generous with the grade corrections we can do! The professor is a HUGE strength. She is so thorough and knowledgeable of the material and I am so honored to have had Steinacker this year. 


Weakness: I felt that a lot of students came into this class having taken AP Physics C and because of that I felt at a disadvantage. The problem sets took me an incredible amount of time. It is hard to ask questions in lecture given the large size, but there is definitely time to ask during office hours.

This course highly favors engineering students and those who have taken physics in the past. Lecture was often very hard to stay concentrated and involved in due to the speed of the lecture and difficulty of problems that are simply rushed through. The exams were also very difficult and similar to pset problems, which were for the most impossible to do without help from the professor or TFs.
difficult and there will always be people in the class that know more than you/know everything

The strength of this course is all in Adriane. She is the most generous and brilliant professor who will teach you anything and be in office hours for essentially forever to help you. The only way this course could be improved would be with a tad more leniency toward the number of psets/maybe making them a tad more forgiving to students who aren't in physical sciences.

The course was well structured and the availability of all course materials made it very conducive to learning. In addition, the frequency and length of office hours and study halls made the problem sets manageable for any student in the course. Overall, the course was very strong and presented many opportunities for students to ask for help.
Yes. It makes you much much smarter

If you need to take a physics class (pre-med, major, etc) I would highly recommend phys 180/181. It's obvious that Steinacker loves what she does and pours her heart and soul into her teaching. You can get a lot out of this class - best of all, you don't need multivariable calculus, which makes this class accessible to everyone.

Take only as a prerequisite for STEM majors.  I would not recommend it to fulfill the pre-med requirements, which can be more easily done with Phys 170/171.  Overall teaching and study requirements are reasonable, but large lecture-based format leaves something to be desired.  Splitting the class up into something similar to Math 112/115, with ~20 students/class, would be much more effective.
If you're interested in engineering or physics, I would recommend this course.

If you need to take physics, this is absolutely the course to take. Professor Steinacker is by far the best professor I've had in any subject, and I'm so glad I decided to take 180/181 over 170/171. The collaborative and supportive atmosphere is ideal.
Yes, professor Steinacker is awesome.
I would not recommend this class for another student because I think there are better alternatives for intro to physics classes.
Avoid if possible.

Yes. It was incredibly well run. From the teacher to the TAs to the peer tutors, everyone was very engaged and knowledge and worked very had to help me learn the material. While the material is tough, the work is worth it.
No.
Only take if you have to, it is a long and hard class.

I think that PHYS 181 teaches you about the world in a more concrete and straightforward way than 171, though I didn't take 171 so I'm not sure if the biological applications are cool enough to outweigh that. 171 definitely appears to be easier.
Any student who seeks to learn classical applications of E&M should take professor Steinacker's class.

I would take this over 171, as the psets get curved to 100 if you average over 90 on them and the final counts for less. Its definitely a lot of work however, youre gonna lose a solid three nights a week to just doing the pset, even if you do them at study hall, which I highly recommend. If you dont have to take physics though, I have no idea  why youd take this class. Also, be aware that you will use calc 3 material in the psets, though the math is explained in class

You probably don't get to choose to take physics, but you do get to choose which version it will be. I would highly recommend 181. I'm premed and I didn't take multivariable calculus and I thought 181 was just as manageable as 180. You will be taught what you need to do and you'll be fine. As far as the content, I thought 181 was more interesting but its also definitely much harder. It harder mathematically, conceptually, and work wise. The psets are even longer and harder this semester (you have to do all 10 problems some weeks...) and there were multiple instances I wrote 20+ pages for a single pset. I took this as a 5th credit with 4 other hard credits and while I'm still alive to write this review, it certainly was incredibly challenging. Consider only taking this as a 4th credit as max.

I would not recommend this to a student unless they had to take an introductory physics course or just really loved physics, in which case I would definitely recommend it. The course is very well-taught and well-administered, but the workload is extremely difficult. That being said, if someone has to take an introductory physics course, I feel that taking a course with Professor Steinacker is the best way to learn a lot and to feel supported while learning difficult content.
Yes, the class is graded very easily, and the exams are pretty simple.

Definitely would not recommend. Course is poorly taught (ie <50% people pay attention during lectures but you have to go due to class participation points), and there is an absurd amount of busy work. Go take Physics 200 or 260 instead. I like the subject of physics but this class almost made me dislike it.
yes

Take this class if you have to. Its a good class but the time commitment is borderline unreasonable and is easy to not keep up with if you aren't taking the class for an explicit reason. The amount of time you will spend on the homework assignments is absurd, and though you certainly learn, its at the expense of your other classes and commitments. If you are torn between taking physics 170/171 and physics 180/181, I would encourage you to take 180/181. 170/171 is about the same time commitment for a course that is less quality than this one.
I would recommend this class if you can take it with Steinacker. Its hard, but you will learn the material.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student if they have any interest in learning physics.

I would highly recommend this course to any student, after 180. Professor Steinacker is so genuine and caring about student learning and she really cares about your life and interests. You learn a ton of physics and at the end are surprised by how much you know and can do.
Yes.

You're probably taking Physics 181 because you have to. With that being said, I do think this course was an amazing introduction to E&M. We covered a lot of ground and managed to go pretty in-depth with most topics, and the way Professor Steinacker taught the material made it easier to manage than I'd anticipated. It's not an easy course, by any means (the exams could be brutal, but the curve was always helpful), but it's a good one.

This course is very hard. It takes an enormous amount of time and effort and if you do not have a strong calculus/physics background, you will do a lot of work for seemingly little reward. Though the opportunity exists to improve your grade along the way, through midterm corrections, assistance at office hours, etc., this course is incredibly stressful and taxing, and you shouldn't take it unless you have many hours to commit to going to office hours and studying. Professor Steinacker does want everyone to succeed and will give help to those who seek it, but that is sometimes not enough. Prepare for a challenge. Take it if you need to or if you find it really fascinating. Otherwise, not really worth the effort.

Take this class with Adriane while you can! She's an amazing teacher and genuinely cares about you doing well (which is doubly impressive considering how many students she has).

However, I definitely would NOT take this course "just for fun" or "for the knowledge." The p-sets are a HUGE amount of work and you'll likely spend multiple afternoons camped out in office hours trying to get them done.
Yes. Even if you are not a physics person Adriane is such a wonderful Professor and tries to make the class as enjoyable as possible!
Yes. Professor Steinacker is great!

Although most people take 181 as some sort of requirement, I would recommend it as a very solid option for the intro physics sequence. Of course I can only speak for my own experience, but I am pre-med and considered doing the 170/171 sequence. It's a little harder to see how 181 is relevant to medicine than it was in 180, but sticking it out and trying to invest in and engage with the work did definitely improve my problem-solving skills. Professor Steinacker's commitment, fairness, and support alone makes it a worthwhile option for fulfilling this requirement, and there are several grade buffers in place that allow everyone to succeed, even those for whom physics is not a primary area of study or an area they've had much prior exposure to.

No. She makes PSETs way too hard for no reason and doesn't cover hardly any of the material necessary to do them. They are a complete waste of time and do not facilitate learning. Her lectures are not intuitive and she doesn't know how to explain things to the students.

I would recommend this course because I feel it does an excellent job of making a student well-equipped for taking further classes in physics and I feel that I will be able to apply what I have learned this semester to future classes.
I would recommend this course to another student, though I'd recommend it with the caveat that the student should be prepared to spend many hours each week doing problem sets.
Yes, the professor is amazing and you will learn a lot.
most students will take it because they have to
Yes, if you need to take introductory physics, definitely take this course. Professor Steinacker is insanely dedicated to her students and there are so many resources to help you do well.
Broke my brain take it

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Physics is a beautiful subject and especially if you need physics for your major, take this course!!! Professor Steinacker is absolutely incredible and she will help you all the way through and ensure that you succeed. Also, you will learn slot in this course from basic reinforcement and mathematical and problem solving skills to really understanding foundational physics concepts upon which much of the sciences stand.

This is one of the best courses at Yale hands down.  Even if you take this class just for the science credit, I would recommend taking it.  Even if you are "not a science person", I guarantee that by the end of it, professor Steinacker will have you singing a different tune, that is how powerful of a teacher she is.  This course reminds me why I chose Yale:  excellent teaching and intellectual stimulation.
Yes! Professor Steinacker is one of the best professors that I've had at Yale, and everything is graded very easily.
A continuation of PHYS 180.  Prof. Steinacker is a great lecturer!
No.
This is a fantastic course, Professor Steinacker is amazing, and you should definitely take it if you want to know anything about physics.
Yes, certainly over the other intro physics courses. Particularly if Steinacker is teaching.
If you have to take it then do so, but I would not take it for fun if you aren't super passionate about physics.
you're probably taking it because you have to , but i would choose this version of physics 2 over 171 etc... just because of the most amazing and caring professor

No, I would not recommend this course to another student. Physics 181 was the most time-consuming class I've ever taken and it was a very negative experience for me overall. The professor is amazing but it is not enough to counteract how difficult I found this class to be. I wish I had taken the Physics 170-171 sequence.
Better than 171
YES take this physics!! Adrianne is a blessing and she's also the best professor you will have on this campus maybe ever. Makes physics 4003029x less painful

Yes, especially if Adriane Steinacker is teaching it. That is absolutely essential. She is a great professor and a lovely person, and I would definitely encourage other students to have the pleasure of being educated by her.

Yes, Professor Steinacker is one of the most caring professors/teachers I have ever met in my entire education. She does her absolute best to make sure you understand things and puts you in a position to succeed.
Yes. If you have to take physics, take it with Steinacker. She is the absolute best. She makes physics doable and she makes this class manageable. She is amazing.

Yes, Professor Steinacker is an amazing professor and wonderful person as well! She really cares about her students and is always willing to help. There are also so many opportunities to get help--office hours and study hall almost everyday. Working on the problem sets with other students and helping each other understand really builds a strong sense of community.

I would not. To be honest, I took 181 instead of 201 because I thought my math wasn't advanced enough for 201. I regret that decision. Much of the concepts of 181 was a repeat of my high school physics, only with much higher difficulty of math and problem solving. From what I heard about 201, it covered many more concepts and was at a similar difficulty to 181.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless it is a requirement. It is very time consuming and a very challenging course.

I would only recommend this class to those deeply interested in Physics, or who have to take this class as a prerequisite. It is simply not worth the emotional strife it'll cause you if you don't have to take this class as a prereq.

This is a wonderful introduction to physics, especially when taught by Dr. Steinacker. Although the PSets require a lot of time, you definitely learn the material and approach exams with a strong level of confidence.
Yes if it is required for your major.
Good intro physics class. Large lecture, so can get dull, but very organized.
Yes. Taking it after 180 is highly recommended.

I would recommend this course to another student because I feel like my physics and mathematical abilities were extensively refined throughout the semester, and I thoroughly enjoyed Professor Steinacker's passion so clearly evident in her teaching.

I would only recommend this course for students with a strong interest in physics or math, in addition to a decent background in both of those subjects. It is so intense that knowing these topics (or having a passion for those topics) is essential.

This is a very challenge class, so really I would not recommend it if you're just looking for a science credit unless you really enjoy physics. Be prepared regardless to have to really put in a great load of time to crunch through the problem sets.
Only if you have taken physics before and are an engineering student. If you are premed, just take 170/171.
it's hard and will make you sad but also you will learn things and the prof is great

Take 180/181 over 170/171 if Adriane is teaching and you can do derivatives and integrals. You don't even need to be good at math, just have been exposed to calculus. You don't need multi to take this class--I haven't taken it and never needed it. Adriane is the person who makes this class a much better experience than 170/171. She's clear and concise; even if the material is challenging, she's fair and kind and cares about students learning and improving. Both physics are hard, but 180/181 with Adriane comes with much more support and much less chaos than my friends in 170/171 talked about.

I would highly recommend taking intro physics with Professor Steinacker because of how thorough she is in her lectures and uploaded notes as well as how inviting and helpful she is during office hours. As a premed, I was worried that taking physics 180/181 was the wrong choice, but I found that my fears were entirely unfounded.
